children.subject:
I agree about the hard classes v points. 

Personally, I am not really concerned with the fastest solution as much as I am concerned with the best answer I could get if this was an exam, since I get the impression that the homework problems more or less mirror difficulty of exam problems (hence if I cannot figure out the homeworks then I will fail the exams). Though I can see the professor's point. After spending days on the palindrome problem, I realized I really missed out a lot of time that I could have spent on other practice problems.
Hmm.. yeah but homework is basically a way to get us studying early. So yeah.. I'm going to turn it in and try to get it all right. Feedback is valuable.

I'm more concerned about driving down my time to solve than about the actual points for the homework. I like the fact that they aren't worth that much but they let you know loud and clear where you need to focus.

Good point.

I'd say this though: it is really hard not to care.

Moreover, I've learned that in hard classes every point matters.

But I totally agree that is more productive to spend time practicing DP than to stress over the fastest possible solution for a problem that we already know how to solve.

Thanks for the post!

history.content:
Can you please stop obsessing over whether you have the fastest possible DP algorithm for the homework 1 problems?  These are a few problems out of roughly 10 homeworks, worth a total of 5% of your grade.  Yes, only 5%!  If you get it wrong (or don't even turn it in), it matters very little for your grade.  It's meant to challenge you.  I don't expect everyone to get them all correct with the fastest possible running time.  If you have a solution your comfortable with, move on to some other practice problems.  It's better to do more practice problems then to kill yourself to get the optimal solution.  On the homework you may even get the same credit for the slightly slower solution as for the optimal one, because it's just a homework!

Also, the homeworks are graded quickly.  We give 0, .5, or 1 point for each problem.  If you get it mostly right you'll get 1 point.  There's no point giving .9 since homeworks are worth so little. Also in the future we might only grade a random subset of the problems.
history.subject: HW's are worth a total of 5%!
